title: Ncell Share Sale Controversy (2023)
description:
In a highly controversial transaction on December 1, 2023, Malaysian conglomerate Axiata Group Berhad announced the sale of its 80% majority stake in Nepal's second-largest telecommunications company, Ncell Axiata Limited. The stake was sold to Spectrlite UK Limited, a newly formed UK-based company owned by Satish Lal Acharya, for $50 million.

The deal immediately sparked public and political outrage due to the immense price discrepancy; Axiata had purchased the same stake in 2016 for $1.365 billion. This has led to widespread allegations of a major tax evasion scheme, political corruption, and a strategic maneuver to circumvent Nepali law. Under the Telecommunications Act, Ncell's assets are expected to be transferred to the state upon the expiry of its license in 2029, a provision the sale could potentially undermine.

Key issues in the case include:

  • Lack of Regulatory Approval: The transaction was executed without the legally required prior approval from the Nepal Telecommunications Authority (NTA).
  • Questionable Buyer: A government probe found that the buyer, Spectrlite UK, was a shell company with nominal capital, lacking the financial or managerial capacity to operate Ncell.
  • Government and Parliamentary Investigations: The Government of Nepal formed a high-level probe committee led by former Auditor General Tanka Mani Sharma. The committee's report, submitted on January 29, 2024, deemed the sale 'unnatural' and recommended that the government not approve it. Multiple parliamentary committees also launched separate investigations.
  • Legal Challenges: A writ petition was filed at the Supreme Court to halt the sale. While the petition was eventually dismissed, the court issued a directive ordering the NTA and Ncell to comply strictly with Nepali laws.

Following the investigations, on March 28, 2024, the NTA formally decided it could not approve the share purchase agreement in its current form, effectively halting the deal.
unverified_info:
The specific amount of money allegedly received by Ganga Dahal, daughter of Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal, as claimed by Member of Parliament Dr. Amaresh Kumar Singh, has not been substantiated with evidence. Dr. Singh alleged she facilitated the deal for a large bribe but stated he would present evidence at a later, appropriate time.

The Prime Minister's Office has officially denied these allegations as 'baseless' and stated that no meetings or conversations, formal or informal, took place between the PM's office and Ncell representatives regarding the sale.
key_allegations: Massive tax evasion through deliberate undervaluation of assets
Political corruption involving high-level officials and their families
Circumvention of laws regarding the transfer of company assets to the state upon license expiry
Violation of telecommunication regulations by proceeding with the sale without prior approval from the Nepal Telecommunications Authority (NTA)
related_entities: Parliamentary State Affairs and Good Governance Committee

locations.other: Country where parent company Axiata Group Berhad is based.
Country where purchasing company Spectrlite UK Limited is registered.

timeline.title: Axiata Acquires Ncell
timeline.description: Malaysian firm Axiata completes the acquisition of an 80% stake in Ncell from Swedish company TeliaSonera for $1.365 billion, a deal which sparked a major capital gains tax dispute.

timeline.title: Axiata Announces Sale of Ncell Stake
timeline.description: Axiata Group Berhad announces it has entered an unconditional Sale and Purchase Agreement to sell its 80% stake in Ncell to Spectrlite UK Limited for $50 million.

timeline.title: MP Alleges Corruption
timeline.description: Independent Member of Parliament Dr. Amaresh Kumar Singh holds a press conference, alleging high-level political corruption in the deal, specifically implicating the Prime Minister's daughter, Ganga Dahal.

timeline.title: Government Forms High-Level Probe Committee
timeline.description: The Government of Nepal forms a five-member high-level committee, chaired by former Auditor General Tanka Mani Sharma Dangal, to investigate the controversial share sale.

timeline.title: Writ Petition Filed at Supreme Court
timeline.description: MP Amaresh Kumar Singh files a writ petition at the Supreme Court seeking to halt the share transaction.

timeline.title: Prime Minister's Office Denies Allegations
timeline.description: The Prime Minister's Office issues a statement refuting the 'baseless' allegations made by MP Singh against the Prime Minister and his daughter.

timeline.title: Parliamentary Committee Grills Prime Minister
timeline.description: The House of Representatives' State Affairs and Good Governance Committee questions Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal over the controversial Ncell deal.

timeline.title: Probe Committee Submits Report
timeline.description: The Tanka Mani Sharma-led probe committee submits its report to the Prime Minister, concluding the deal is 'unnatural' and recommends against its approval by the government.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Issues Order
timeline.description: The Supreme Court dismisses the writ petition filed by MP Singh but issues an instructive order to the Nepal Telecommunications Authority and Ncell to strictly comply with all prevailing Nepali laws regarding the transaction.

timeline.title: NTA Decides Against Approving the Deal
timeline.description: The Nepal Telecommunications Authority (NTA) formally decides that it cannot approve the Ncell share purchase agreement in its current form, citing findings from the government's investigation.
